Key Arguments: The bill is seen as a top-down, heavy-handed approach that will degrade public trust in institutions.
The bill will have the opposite effect of its intended purpose, decreasing trust and fostering disunity.
The exemption of government-authorized content from the bill is viewed as hypocritical and contemptuous.
The proposal is compared to authoritarian regimes, suggesting it is not suitable for a democratic country like Australia.
Emphasizes the importance of freedom of speech as a basic human right.
Notable Quotes: This proposed bill to combat 'misinformation and disinformation' must be wholly rejected.
This is the kind of proposal that someone might expect under a Soviet-style regime. Not in Australia.
Freedom of speech is a basic right of every human being even if we don't agree with what they are saying.
